question: Brenda -- ?
answer: Steed -- ?!

question: Mother. I thought you were burglars.
answer: Brenda and I thought we'd drop in.

question: Something in the wind?
answer: Weather's turning nasty.

question: You didn't come to talk about the weather, surely.
answer: Oh yes I did. I want you to meet somebody. I expect you'll like her.

question: Thank you ... 'Please answer the Telephone.' Kippers ...?
answer: May I help you, madam ...

question: Mr. John Steed, please.
answer: I'm afraid that's impossible.

question: Impossible?
answer: You are female?

question: As you see.
answer: Then you can't come in.

question: I have an appointment.
answer: No women. Not in Boodles. Not since 1922.

question: Really -- what happened in 1922? Thank you so much. I can find Mr. Steed myself ...
answer: Doctor Peel, I presume?

question: And you must be Steed. Please don't get up.
answer: I was about to throw in the towel.

question: I had a spot of bother at the door.
answer: I shouldn't wonder. Not a woman inside Boodles since --

question: 1922. Why the kippers?
answer: Red herring would have been too obvious, don't you think?

question: So what was all this -- some sort of test?
answer: Congratulations, you've penetrated a bastion of male privilege. I guessed you weren't a stickler for Tradition, doctor.

question: Whereas you are.
answer: Dyed in the wool. But I can admire someone who doesn't play by the rules.

question: Rules are made to be broken.
answer: Not by me. Play by the rules, Doctor, or the game is nothing.

question: And just what is the game?
answer: I say, this is all terribly formal. Must I go an calling you Dr. Peel?

question: Under the circumstances, you may call me Mrs. Peel.
answer: Much better.

question: And now that we've settled the matter of honorifics, will you kindly explain why you wished me to meet you?
answer: I didn't. Mother did.

question: Mother?
answer: I expect you'll like him. Tea time -- four o'clock. Mustn't be late. A word of warning. Don't take the macaroon. Mother's favorite.

question: That's better. I much prefer a womb with view, don't you, Mrs. Peel? Shall I be mother? I expect you're wondering where you are.
answer: Don't tell me

question: Close. We're so hush-hush, even we know nothing about it. Now let's see, there's coconut cake, date and walnut; I recommend the rum baba ...
answer: Hmmm ...

question: Think she really killed those agents?
answer: She may not know. Theory goes she may be very ill.

question: Amnesia?
answer: Possibly. Split personality ...

question: Insane ... ?
answer: Who knows? If Dr. Darling is right, you should watch out.

question: Why?
answer: She may try to kill you.

question: Peel? Did she know?
answer: Still doesn't. Better safe than sorry. She was in a dangerous game, Steed. High stakes. She may prove to be a risk. If she is, there's only one solution. Termination.

question: Anyone particular in mind?
answer: You.

question: You're a lady of hidden talents, Mrs. Peel ...
answer: I've no intention of hiding them ...

question: Scientist ... ... marksman ... ... swordsman ... ... To what do you attribute your overachievements?
answer: My father always wanted a boy.

question: Really? I fail to see the connection.
answer: I had a feeling you would. Touche!

question: I take your point.
answer: Do you?

question: Yes indeed. I need protection.
answer: I thought we were on our way.

question: Oh, absolutely, but Trubshaw's a man worth meeting. No point setting out half shod.
answer: Or half cocked.

question: I couldn't agree more. Thank you, Trubshaw.
answer: Steed, we really must be --

question: Ahh. Perfect fit. The luxury of a hand-made shoe. As unique as a face or a fingerprint. Or should I say DNA?
answer: You can but I wish you wouldn't ...

question: Thank you, Trubshaw ...
answer: That place is so absurd, so out of date ...

question: Do you really think so? Press that button, would you? Tea? Sorry. Didn't mean to interrupt your flow of oratory ...
answer: You know what I mean. This car -- and you. Nobody walks around like that. Milk?

question: Not all Tradition is bad, Mrs. Peel. No thank you.
answer: But why? What's the point?

question: A Gentleman has to have a code. This is part of mine. A uniform. Think of it as my suit of shining armor.
answer: And I suppose you're the knight.

question: The most unpredictable piece on the board. And always ready to protect his queen.
answer: That's predictable. When I find a queen in need of protection I'll let you know.

question: I'm hoping you will.
answer: Sir August Merryweather ... why are we seeing him first?

question: As per mother's instructions.
answer: Do we always follow Mother's instructions?

question: For a man in my position --
answer: Just what is your position, if you don't mind my asking. How did a stuffed shirt like you get into this line of work?

question: They call me in when they've reached a dead end. Freelance. Like yourself.
answer: I have no choice. Why should you risk your life?

question: After our fencing match, I was rather hoping you would do the risking. More tea?
answer: No thanks.

question: I meant me. According to Mother, Sir August owns half of the Highlands. A millionaire. Former head of Special Projects at the Ministry. Now ...
answer: An eccentric recluse?

question: Not so much eccentric. More barking mad. He has a wife called June. And a daughter somewhere -- Julie.
answer: June, July ... August?

question: The family does seem to be somewhat meteorologically inclined.
answer: Any other vices?

question: All of a piece, really. A fanatical weatherman. Chairman of BROLLY. British Royal Organisation For Lasting Liquid Years. Thinks British weather has been tampered with by ... aliens.
answer: So ... I distract him while you snoop around? How?

question: Small talk. Try the weather.
answer: Original ... Missus ... Sir August ... ? Sir August ... ?

question: I've come to apply for membership in Brolly --
answer: You don't get rain like you used to in England. A good shower that's the ticket. Stiffens resolve, puckers the spirit, quells the namby-pamby in a man.

question: I so agree. How did you acquire a taste for it?
answer: Out in India. So character-forming for the British. Not the heat. Good Lord, no. The rain, dash it. A good monsoon. Fifteen inches overnight. A whole week of lovely rain. I remember one summer in Jaipur ... You

question: Have we met?
answer: You mean you don't recall?? Ah, Lady June ...

question: Thank you, Lady -- June ...
answer: Ah, beautiful. Just as he promised.

question: Promised? Who promised?
answer: There, look! Imagine being caught out in a blow like that!

question: Manners, Mrs. Peel. Ah, Brenda ... Mrs. Peel?
answer: You should be dead. How do you feel?

question: Strange.
answer: You were very lucky. Four shots to the heart. I found you after I slipped away from Sir August. Mother brought you here. Not me you should thank.

question: I wasn't about to.
answer: I mean your man Trubshaw. Your bullet-proof waistcoat. I thought you were just overdressed.

question: I might say the same.
answer: Mother and Dr. Darling have me under observation. They think I tried to kill you.

question: Why should they think that?
answer: You told them. You said I arrived on a camel, shot you four times. Left you for dead.

question: Frankly that's how I remember it.
answer: But that's absurd. I may not be over-fond of you, Steed, but it's not my style.

question: Perhaps your memory plays tricks, Mrs. Peel.
answer: That's possible. Sir August was convinced he'd met me before. But I'd never met him. Another odd thing. When it rained, he said it was just as someone had promised.

question: Did he say who?
answer: No. But he must know. Incidentally, my double left you with this.

question: An invitation. To a 'formal picnic'...?
answer: Did you say formal? I must dress.

question: I must say, you look more your old self --
answer: You mean my other self ...

question: Either way ... may I ask
answer: I should have thought that was obvious ... I'm in mourning.

question: I can't wait to see afternoon.
answer: Where's the picnic?

question: For you, Mrs. Peel.
answer: Another invitation. 38 Marlborough Terrace ...

question: Hm ... A Veuve-Cliquot '56 ... But he bites the end of his Monte Cristos ... ? Clearly, we're dealing with a maniac. Colonel Crabtree. International Satellite Systems. Formerly of the Ministry.
answer: How on earth can you tell?

question: Elementary, Mrs. Peel. Trubshaw isn't the only shoemaker still practicing his trade ...
answer: Very good, Steed ... What's that?

question: What on earth?
answer: Any ideas?

question: Well, he was a fellow of the Royal Zoological Society ...
answer: Is that written in his shoe?

question: Common knowledge, Mrs. Peel ...
answer: She had this in her mouth. There, there...

question: Mrs. Peel -- ?
answer: Ask not for whom the telephone rings ...

question: No, please! I beg you ...
answer: Walk over to the window ...

question: Let it be rain, please let it be --
answer: Stay by the window. By the window.

question: Impossible.
answer: Not quite. This is my field.

question: Is there anything that isn't?
answer: The Prospero Project was started by my husband. It was an early attempt to solve the problems of global warming. In theory, climate engineering is entirely feasible. We thought of injecting a chemical cocktail into the atmosphere by laser and satellite. A 'quick fix'...

question: Filling in mother nature's blind spots ... ?
answer: Exactly. There'd been earlier attempts to pump carbon dioxide into deep sea. Propane gas mostly. In small quantities it captures chlorine. Protects the ozone layer. But it proved impractical. Too bulky ...

question: But if someone miniaturized the process...
answer: That's what we were working on.

question: The hot and cold war ...
answer: New orders. The penultimate phase. Now fully operational ... We're not yet open for business, I'm afraid.

question: Shame. I was recommended. By a friend.
answer: Really?

question: Sir August Merryweather? I was looking for something relaxing. Say, a Tuscan hillside in June?
answer: Normally, we'd be eager to oblige --

question: Seriously?
answer: Of course. Natural weather delivered to your door on demand. Down your phoneline. For limited periods.

question: You don't say. How real does it feel?
answer: As real as you wish. Hot or cold. Humid or dry. Anything you like. Within reason.

question: There are limits?
answer: The technology is brand new. Soon it will be more powerful. We anticipate a huge demand. Leave us your number. We'll be in touch.

question: No need. I'll call again.
answer: My car. I'll drive.

question: A day in the country ...
answer: Three agents killed by bad weather...

question: ... And by you, Mrs. Peel ...
answer: Then a mad millionaire. Head of a secret defense establishment. A group of eccentrics obsessed by weather ...

question: ... And by you, Mrs. Peel. Everything points to you. No sisters? No undiscovered twin?
answer: Not that I know of. Explanation?

question: According to Dr. Darling, you're a psychopathic personality with schizophrenic delusions, suffering from recurring amnesia based on traumatic repression, leading to outbursts of anti-social and violent behavior. Q.E.D.
answer: Is that what you think?

question: Oh, well ... Just my type, Mrs. Peel. Do you always drive this fast?
answer: Have I trespassed on a male prerogative? We're being followed. I saw him at Trubshaw's ... Hold on ...

question: Oh, dear -- Cocky little bastard. I hope he was a baddy.
answer: I feel sure of it.

question: I'm Alice. Mother said you'd be on your way. Mrs. Peel with you?
answer: She was ...

question: You with Mother or Father?
answer: Both, actually.

question: Good. Glad to see they're together at last. They don't get along. Promotion. Top job. Most unfair. Quite a fuss at the Ministry.
answer: You don't say. Like looking for a needle in a ... What, Lady Disdain? Are you yet breathing?

question: You don't say. Like looking for a needle in a ... What, Lady Disdain? Are you yet breathing?
answer: Barely.

question: You will let me know if you find that queen who's in need of protection, won't you?
answer: This must be the last straw.

question: Here's the one that broke the camel's back.
answer: Someone didn't want us to get to the party.

question: I wouldn't shake that too hard. The weather might turn nasty.
answer: Quite a collection.

question: If nature gives a man a collector's mind, it doesn't matter what he collects. Butterflies. Old China. Penny farthings. A true collector grows more obsessive as the years pass.
answer: Your voice -- it's so familiar ...

question: We have met ...
answer: Peter ... ? I must be dreaming ...

question: Peter ... ? I must be dreaming ...
answer: Listen... Very much alive. Darling, it's me...

question: Peter ... Impossible ... how?
answer: For you ... all for you ... Don't be afraid, darling. Don't run away. I forgive you, Emma. I know you left me. But I still love you. Do you still have my ring? I need it.

question: Where am I?
answer: The Winslow Home for Retired Lepidoptorists. I'm so sorry I struck you, Mrs. Peel. Please forgive me. I thought you were someone else ...

question: Was I?
answer: I expect that's for you to know and me to find out ...

question: I want you to say the first thing that comes into your head when I say these words. Do you understand ... ? Blue ...
answer: ... bottle ...

question: Red ...
answer: ... head ...

question: White ...
answer: Knight ...

question: Black...
answer: ... death ...

question: Love...
answer: ... death ...

question: Flower ...
answer: ... power ...

question: Nature ...
answer: ... preserve...

question: Secret ...
answer: ... love...

question: Hope...
answer: ... love ...

question: Fear ...
answer: ... love ...

question: Peter ...
answer: ... Piper picked a peck of pickled peppers how many pecks of pickled peppers did Peter Peel -- ? How long have I been here?

question: Three days.
answer: Do you get paid by the hour?

question: Do you get paid by the hour?
answer: You are here under observation, Mrs. Peel. You must answer Dr. Darling's questions

question: I resign.
answer: You need treatment, Mrs. Peel. You can't resign.

question: Watch me.
answer: Don't open that, Mrs. Peel!

question: What are you trying to do to me?
answer: We want to help...!

question: I thought I was a widow. My husband ... the only man I ever loved ... is dead. For the rest of my life I have to live with that.
answer: The death of Peter Peel was a great loss. To us all ...

question: Peter Peel was a first class agent. A senior operative. 'X' department Special operations. He was engaged in top secret research. Top priority. Government approved.
answer: The Institute ... the funding ...

question: A cover ... for us. I'm sorry...
answer: So all that time. Our work, our research was for you ... for this? And the accident -- The official investigation ...

question: ... was written by me. It was sabotage, Mrs. Peel.
answer: Who?

question: So I'm still ...
answer: Under suspicion. Everyone died in the explosion, Mrs. Peel. You were the only survivor ... This is an official matter, Mrs. Peel. No need to take it personally. Where are you going?

question: To find out who killed my husband.
answer: The doors and walls are monitored, Mrs. Peel. This is a very secure establishment.

question: You followed me.
answer: Orders.

question: To kill me?
answer: Nothing personal.

question: A long way down.
answer: Careful. You might fall.

question: I could save you the trouble.
answer: No trouble.

question: Because you always obey orders ...
answer: Always. Except ...

question: Yes ... ?
answer: ... when I don't. It comes down to one thing, Mrs. Peel. Trust.

question: And do you trust me?
answer: I could be convinced, if ... I knew who poisoned me in the maze. That kiss ...

question: It wasn't me; you have my word.
answer: I need proof. It was longer. On the lips. Much longer. Approximately ... fifteen seconds.

question: ... Ready? ... Four ... seven ... ni-... Mmm ... what are you doing?
answer: Keeping a stiff upper lip?

question: Is that all? So I'm in the clear? But you did suspect me.
answer: Not for a moment.

question: You're playing games.
answer: Aren't we all, Mrs. Peel?

question: I thought you played by the rules.
answer: I thought you didn't.

question: I'm playing to win.
answer: Winning isn't everything.

question: Please don't tell me it's how you play the game.
answer: After you -- Mrs. Peel ...

question: No, after you.
answer: You don't trust me?

question: As far as you trust me. When it happens, Steed, you'll be the first to know ... Who could that be?
answer: No -- don't answer it ... That's it. The phones trigger the explosions -- Don't -- don't answer it -- ! Get down -- get down -- it's going to explode -- ! Mother? How did you find me? I told Mother I took care of you.

question: You lied.
answer: I equivocated. But you're not their big worry at present. It's Dr. Darling

question: Drat. Someone wants to implicate you in this affair, Mrs. Peel. Any idea who?
answer: No idea who. No idea why ...

question: Teddy bears, cuckoo clocks, toys All children's things ...
answer: ... Or grown-ups, who still like to be children.

question: Quite. Any childhood friends? Enemies?
answer: Not to speak of. Peter and I were both loners. There was nobody.

question: Very well. I have a friend who might be of assistance. He's at the Ministry. We'd better be careful.
answer: I'm a wanted woman, I know ...

question: His name's Jones. 'Invisible' Jones.
answer: Why's he called 'Invisible'?

question: You'll find out.
answer: Aren't you coming?

question: Ah, here we are. Steed asked me to play a hunch
answer: Peter's brother? But --

question: Half-brother to be precise. Now let's see ... Eton, Cambridge ... research into robotics and plastics. Overtaken by Peter's work on the physics of climate change ...
answer: I know all this.

question: Do you also know that during your final experiment, your halfbrother- in-law was under surveillance?
answer: Surveillance? By whom?

question: Father. She gave him an 'all clear' after a security test by Dr. Darling.
answer: Who's now vanished.

question: Makes two of us.
answer: Are you suggesting that Dr. Darling and Valentine were somehow in this together? But that's absurd.

question: What's that you're wearing?
answer: It's called Black Leather.

question: Intoxicating. Here, have one of these.
answer: What is it?

question: Limpet bomb. Small, very compact. From Trubshaw's.
answer: When all this is over, we simply must get you out of that suit.

question: You first.
answer: Shall we? Trubshaw again? What now?

question: Snuff. I must insist you try some. They're playing your song, Mrs. Peel.
answer: 'The Merry Widow?' I might have known. Where's the reception?

question: Oh, hello ...
answer: We want Mrs. Peel.

question: Dead, I'm afraid.
answer: You disobeyed an order, Steed. Mrs. Peel is dangerous; she cannot be trusted.

question: I think she can. Can you?
answer: I shall summon security.

question: Bad news. Father's looking for you. Where are those bloody ministers?
answer: Have a look at this.

question: It's almost May, for heaven sake.
answer: Gentlemen, ladies. Forgive the breach of protocol. An emergency --

question: Quick --it'll protect you -- After him, Mrs. Peel! Go -- !
answer: Anyone ever tell you you look like a housefly? Anyone else need a lift?

question: I thought it was Cinderella who lost her slipper ...
answer: This time the shoe's on the other foot. You said a hand-made shoe was as good as a photo-fit or D.N.A.? Well, all we have to do is find the shoe that fits ...

question: I'll be back ...
answer: Where are you going?

question: Laying in supplies, Mrs. Peel weather may get very nasty and I've no umbrella ...
answer: You needn't bother. I can't drag you further into this. After all, I am still the chief suspect.

question: No bother. Mother and Father think I've joined you. I might as well.
answer: But --

question: Oh, and by the way, I think it's about time you got rid of that chip on your shoulder.
answer: If you'd been through what I have, you wouldn't --

question: A microtag. One of Mother's little toys. There you are. Free at last.
answer: Prince Charming, I presume. Your name is ... Oh my God ...

question: 'X' marks the spot. The shoes were delivered to ... an island in Hyde Park. Surrounded by the Serpentine. On the site of a former Ministry installation...
answer: ... and now?

question: Privately owned by ...
answer: Let me guess

question: Very good, Mrs. Peel ...
answer: I shall need a small plane.

question: You're not venturing alone, surely.
answer: I'm going to find out who killed my husband. Will you take these documents to Steed?

question: Of course.
answer: Tell him I said ... goodbye.

question: Where's Mrs. Peel?
answer: I was hoping you could tell me.

question: You're getting yourself into terrible trouble, my son. Weather's turning very nasty -- and so am I.
answer: I'm going to follow up on a hunch of my own. If I'm right, Mrs. Peel is innocent and you have a mole.

question: Where?
answer: In your operation.

question: Congratulations, Mrs. Peel. You have been a worthy opponent. You have tracked us down. You are within an ace of winning.
answer: This isn't a game.

question: Quite right, but we still make the rules.
answer: Rules are made to be broken.

question: People, too.
answer: Then who wins?

question: You.
answer: Darling Emma -- yes, we

question: But you died -- in the explosion ...
answer: Oh, no. I arranged the explosion. A slight miscalculation -- my face was burned beyond recognition. Fortunately my research into plastics came in handy ...

question: Dr. Darling, Peter ... all you ...
answer: An unholy trinity ...

question: You killed my husband.
answer: For starters. Of course I had to kill the Teddy Bears, as well ...

question: Too many cooks --
answer: Spoil the majority shareholders. In Wonderland Weather. I planned everything, even the Ministry recruiting you ...

question: But I found you. All the clues led me here ...
answer: Of course. I planned that, too.

question: But -- why?
answer: You disappoint me, Emma. Can't you guess? For you. It was all for you ...

question: 'Our revels now are ended.'
answer: Oh, no, Emma. They've only just begun ...

question: Think of this as your second wedding feast ...
answer: I'm already married ...

question: Come, come, you're a widow -- a most attractive widow. Now I think of it, we'll need a bridesmaid. Here. My latest model. A compound of plastics and sensor chips. A big improvement on the old X404s. The poor thing is quite fond of me. Emma, say hello to Emma. You know, I believe she's actually jealous.
answer: Valentine, listen to me ...

question: Right, bridesmaid. Now what have I left out? Oh, yes, I know
answer: Ring?

question: How silly of me -- let me make you comfortable first ... That's better. I say, isn't this where you came in? It's impenetrable, by the way ...
answer: You're mad.

question: Steed
answer: How did you guess?

question: You reek of Mrs. Peel's Black Leather ...
answer: It was you who gave Valentine Peel his security clearance ... you're the mole who betrayed the Ministry.

question: Mother betrayed me. She was going to replace me with a younger Father. Errand boy that's all I was. 'Find Steed...'
answer: Well, you found me. Have a sniff of this, why don't you? Careful, the scent can be overpowering ...

question: People expect weather to be free. They're used to it. I call that a denial of freedom. No freedom of choice. An abuse of human rights. They buy water, electricity, gas. Why shouldn't they be able to buy their own weather if they want to? If they have a little incentive ...
answer: Such as?

question: Destruction of their local weather systems. I can zap a thousand Chernobyls into the air.
answer: The result would be ...

question: Chaos. Transport paralysis. Crop failure. Economic disaster. Frostbite or sunburn ... on a massive scale. You've seen a few samples...
answer: Then what's stopping you?

question: One very small thing. A diamond 'cyclone' chip. A thousand times more information on a fraction of the size. If I possess that, my powers would be unlimited. My dear half-brother was developing it. But he suspected sabotage. He gave the chip to ... you, 'Mrs.' Peel. I want you. But also your ring. The missing piece of the jigsaw. I tried to get you to give it to me as Peter; I tried to steal it from you as Dr. Darling. As myself I'll be a bit less subtle. With this ring my plan will be complete.
answer: How Wagnerian ... Do you mean to say you've waited all these years because you couldn't create a chip on your own? That would have amused Peter.

question: Speaking of Peter, there's more good news
answer: What are my choices?

question: Choices?
answer: I'll never marry you.

question: Start the countdown. Action stations. Five minutes ...
answer: Congratulations. The clouds are on course ...

question: To explode. London will be ashes.
answer: Not yet! They haven't heard our terms ... !

question: Are you insane? Stop the program and you activate the auto-destruct!
answer: But all those people -- !

question: My dear. I wouldn't want you to miss the grand finale ... Find her. Kill her ... John Steed.
answer: Valentine Peel. I see you've gone back to using your original face.

question: The last one you'll ever see.
answer: Perish the thought.

question: Did they tell you at Eton that I was fencing champion, too?
answer: They said you were a very naughty boy.

question: You're better than I expected.
answer: I was at Harrow ...

question: But did they teach you this?
answer: Bang-bang ... you're dead.

question: You wish.
answer: One shot -- for emergencies.

question: That's not playing by the rules.
answer: Rules are made to be broken.

question: If you say so.
answer: I do.

question: You said ... one shot.
answer: Did I? My mistake.

question: I wouldn't do that, if I were you.
answer: Mrs. Peel -- !

question: Bullet-proof waistcoats -- just the thing. I get mine from Trubshaw's. We'll be off now, won't we, darling? We wouldn't want to miss the fireworks. Figure it out if you can, Steed ...
answer: You must be joking ...

question: Fool ...
answer: That will do.

question: Aren't you forgetting about something?
answer: You are, and it's behind you.

question: Come, come. You don't really expect me to fall for -- Let go, you ... idiot ...
answer: I think she really likes you ... Where's Mrs. Peel?

question: Ugh ...
answer: Emma! Emma ...

question: Emma! Emma ...
answer: Steed?

question: Mrs. Peel?
answer: What kept you?

question: The plot. Hello, we must be going ...
answer: Quick!

question: 'The owl and the pussycat went to sea -'
answer: '... in a beautiful pea green boat...'

question: A fine night, Mrs. Peel ...
answer: Still a bit chilly ...

question: English weather. You know, after all we've been through, I should say we deserve a long holiday ...
answer: Have you any place in mind?

question: As a matter of fact I have ...
answer: I don't recall Siberia being this warm, Steed.

question: It's the latest thing, Mrs. Peel.
answer: Our little paradise -- just made for two?

question: Not quite. Our chaperon.
answer: Pity your mother came, too ...
